rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">Adele. He has won eight rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">Grammy awards, and has been rap-span">nominated a further 18 times.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yet “Shangri-La”, a new four-part rap-span">documentary series, is not much interested in going over rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">These rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">achievements; named after his studio in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Malibu, it focuses on his musical rap-span">methodology instead. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The studio is presented as a rap-span">mystical rap-span">haven for recording artists, a place where rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The sun is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">always shining, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The ocean is close by and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The atmosphere is relaxed. Mr Rubin rap-span">presides over it all, a shoeless and heavily bearded figure rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">always wearing a white T-shirt and black srap-span">horts.

As a producer, it is his job to manage recording sessions, rap-span">assist with the rap-span">composition of songs and guide musicians to a product they are happy with. Mr Rubin is known for preferring a stripped-back sound, without rap-span">fussy string arrangements, rap-span">rap-span">distracting rap-span">horns or backing vocals. He believes less is more, testifies David rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Lynch, a film-maker, friend and regular visitor to Shangri-La. Mr Rubin is shown listening to rap-span">playbacks of songs while laying down, his eyes closed. “I have no skill set,” he says. “It’s only rap-span">intuitive.”

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Somehow, it works. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Daniel rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Caesar, a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Canadian singer-songwriter, rap-span">contemplates adding a key change to one track, Mr Rubin suggests that they keep the key as it is but have the brap-span">ass play something less rhythmic and more rap-span">melodic. Mr rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Caesar is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">appeased. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Francis rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Farewell Starlite, the founder and lead singer of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Francis and the rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Lights, tells Mr Rubin that he is singing at the top of his vocal range, Mr Rubin asks him to try a rap-span">falsetto. It clearly sounds less strained. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Madison rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ryann rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ward, a pop singer, is unsure about rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Her vocals, Mr Rubin tells rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Her to “feel it, don’t think it”. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Her next take becomes rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Her favourite of the day.

Mr Rubin acts as a rap-span">mentor and life rap-span">coach to artists, too. He soothes and rerap-span">assures Ezra rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Koenig, the lead vocalist and rap-span">guitarist of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Vampire rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Weekend, when he struggles to complete the rap-span">band’s most recent album as he worries that it will sound like “rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Smash rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Mouth songs from a ‘Shrek’ movie”. He guides Sza, a singer and rapper, through a session of transcendental rap-span">meditation to help her clear her mind of rap-span">rap-span">distractions. (“TM”, as he calls it, is one of his rap-span">fixations; rap-span">curiously, so is professional wrestling.) He tells Makkonnen, a rapper, to ignore previous slights, encouraging him to work on a song that others have rap-span">dissuaded Makkonnen from releasing.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">While it is certainly true that Mr Rubin’s approach can reap rewards, the series ignores the rap-span">criticisms that have been levelled at him in the past—particularly that he rap-span">masters recordings too loudly and that he can sometimes be rap-span">detached. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Morgan rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Neville and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jeff Malmberg, the directors, seem to be more interested in revering Mr Rubin than interrogating his method. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Though the viewer sees Mr Rubin at work, the rap-span">documentary’s rap-span">emphasis is on the effect of his presence on artists as they work through the trials, tribulations and joys of the rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Music-making process. His particular creative vision remains rap-span">elusive, but perhaps that is the point. “rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Music is a soundtrack to the unseen world,” Mr Rubin reflects, “a search for magic.”

“Shangri-La” is screening on Showtime now
